[Petruchio] Sun Feb 10 10:08:33 UTC 2002:

I have made A Discovery ™

I really wasn't familiar with [crazyinsomniac|crazy]'s custom title patch before I looked at the code itself. It's actually pretty neat; I've often been vexed by not knowing the section something was in, or what its node id was.

However, allowing arbitrary text into the head of every document onsite can lead to unexpected effects. I invite you to try this as a custom title string:

%T (%S ID: %N) - %D

Yes, you can sneak custom stylesheets onto the site this way. My question is, is this unintended use a potential problem? After all, it only changes the site for the user, not for anyone else. I cannot think of a serious abuse which would make use of this. I must admit, I'm dying to post and tell everyone how to do this... but it seems the sort of thing that should be blessed by a Higher Authority first. Please let me know what you think.

[grinder] 2002-02-10 10:58:07 ZULU

I think it's a nifty hack, and should be permitted, much like the way you can add additional elements in the Location: field on homenodes. I am a happy user of crazy's patch. It's nice to see the node id easily in the title. Helps with replying, especially using Mozilla's tabbed interface.

[jcwren] 2002-02-10 15:44:00 GMT

Perhaps we could consider adding a %C option that would allow pointing to an offset style sheet, and not require the user worry about specify the link tags and such. I don't know what all the security issues would be, but perhaps even consider permitting the ability of a user to upload a style sheet, much like a monk picture (since not everyone has a server they can point to).

[Petruchio] Sun Feb 10 17:32:37 UTC 2002:

I entirely agree, [jcwren|jc]; I would prefer some formal mechanism for allowing offsite stylesheets. And I think the hack is small enough that a separate mechanism is reasonable... I daresay I could cook up something proper with its own entry in the [User Settings] in a half hour or so.

And actually, this gets to the root of my misgivings about announcing this hack to the teeming masses. I want stylesheets; always have. And I think it's just incredibly cool looking at my own warped monastery as I write this. But it's not my site, and I've not been given the go-ahead to add such a feature. Even though this is merely a discovery, and not a real action on my part, I don't feel it's quite right to just go ahead and sneak them in by exploiting a bug, and then tell everyone how they can do it, too. At the moment, it's still fun and games; if I post, that's different.

This behavior can stopped very easily by adding a filter to [crazyinsomniac]'s code, swapping < and > for < and >. I will be happy, with [jcwren]'s assistance, to take care of this... or, naturally, to let someone else do so, if that's desired. I'll also be happy to code up the capacity for a stylesheet link, if that is deemed good. I'm also willing to simply write a post on what I've discovered, or keep my public mouth shut indefinitely on the subject and ignore the whole thing (and until I've been given instruction on the matter, I'll do the latter). Sorry to lay another decision at your door, [vroom], but you're the man. Speak, and it shall be done.

[chromatic] - 2001-08-23 around 4:40 pm GMT

Everything allows for code to be modified on the fly, even code that's considered part of node objects or node display. Unfortunately, it's optimized for the uncommon case, checking to see if the code needs to be recompiled on every hit. As reads are much, much more common than writes (at least 100 to 1), that's a big performance penalty.

What makes things worse is that there's no good way to share memory between mod_perl child processes. They'll get further and further out of sync. If there are five kids, and I modify an htmlpage in one kid, the other four will each have to recompile and to cache it.

My potential solution is to rework the forking slightly. Instead of allowing Apache to prefork several children, we'll limit it to one kid. That'll be the new parent. It will receive new requests and fork off children on its own. The difference is, each child will report back to the parent any modified nodes that need to be recompiled. The parent will then recompile the node, install the new code in the appropriate stash for the object or wherever, and cache the new node.

The next child to be forked off will use the same memory pages as the parent. It'll be much more up to date and ought to use less memory. We can remove a lot of redundant "is this updated?" checks in the children. Moving nodetypes to first-class objects can also give us a speed win, if we avoid AUTOLOAD in Everything::HTML.

I have a small, non-Apache proof of concept already.

[chromatic]'s Thoughts on Everything 0.8x and Everything 1.0:

My completely impractical, more work for vroom and nate and maybe CowboyNeal suggestion is to think about migrating PM to the Everything 1.0 codebase. Part of that is pragmatic. I know Everything 0.9x and 1.0, and I can work with 0.8, but it's not documented. There have been several impressive feature enhancements (code caching, API improvements, Form Objects!), and there's even a manual.

Of course, it tends to be slower (though I have a nasty mod_perl idea to fix that for good), and there are a lot of existing nodes that will have to be converted.

The bulk of the PM database made up of general questions and answers, in the message nodeball. vroom 's produced a version of this that runs on 1.0. I don't know if there are any schema changes, but translating nodes between versions is straightforward.

The big work will be translating superdocs, htmlpages, and just about any other site construct that uses things that have changed in the API. There are probably a couple hundred of them. vroom's probably the only guy who understands them at this point, but they can't be too hard to decipher.

If there are a handful of people in pmdev with the time and the inclination, perhaps someone could set up a 1.0 site and vroom could make some of these nodes available, for porting purposes. If everything can be updated to take advantage of Everything 1.0, it might be easier to port the entire site.

Of course, this is just my opinion. It's a bit of work, and it's not my call whether or not vroom 's even interested in such a project. Also, the rough consensus among Everything developers is that 1.0 is slower than 0.8, which is why Everything 2 isn't running the latest and greatest code. Brian Aker gave me an idea on how to speed this up, though, by abusing mod_perl. It's worth considering.
